sampled: A man creates a time travel device to find a cure for his ailing wife, successfully achieving his goal, only to discover he is unable to return. Dr. Hadley sits tensely in the bustling terminal, clutching a locked briefcase—a product of years of dedicated research and significant financial investment. He had managed to develop technology to leap forward in time, determined to save his wife. Upon arrival, however, his time machine was confiscated and destroyed under an obscure law. Undeterred, Hadley focused on curing the disease, deciding he'd address the issue of returning once he had succeeded. He avoided searching for her, fearing he’d find only a grave if he failed. The loudspeaker crackled overhead, announcing, "All passengers for 2013, please proceed to gate 5." Hadley rose cautiously, ensuring the briefcase remained secure. Navigating through the crowd, he joined the line at gate 5. "Good afternoon, sir," the attendant greeted with a smile as Hadley approached. "Boarding pass, please." "I... I don't have one, but I must get on this transport," Hadley pleaded. "I'm sorry, sir, no boarding pass, no entry," the attendant replied, accustomed to such situations. "You can purchase a ticket at the ticket office for five hundred thousand dollars." "I don’t have that kind of money," Hadley admitted. "Then I'm afraid you cannot proceed," the attendant said, motioning to the next passenger, who pushed past Hadley in line. Defeated, Hadley exited the terminal, contemplating whether he should search for the grave he hoped to never find.

You tell Death that you'll never grow weary of life, regardless of its length. Death wagers that you will, granting you true immortality. After experiencing the universe's end twice, you're still going strong, leaving Death puzzled. "How?" Death asks, his voice as chilling as ever. "After countless eons of heartache, war, and hatred, how do you remain enamored with life?" "It's quite simple," I respond. "You, of all beings, should appreciate the cycle." "The cycle! Ha!" Death scoffs. "Indeed, the cycle. I've witnessed it countless times." "About thirty, actually." "Right, thirty times, and each is as breathtaking as the last." "How? You've lost everyone you've ever cherished, watched the world crumble repeatedly. How can you still cherish that cycle? You know I mentioned it as a jest." "That doesn't matter to me. I adore the cycle of life. Because just when I think I’ve seen it all, the universe reveals its beauty anew. Every time we witness the cycle, we see everything happen again—the explosion, the stars' formation and destruction, stars giving rise to planets, and eventually humans. Ah, humans. They create stunning art, explore Earth’s heights and ocean depths, love and lose, fail and try anew, craft grand spectacles, and pray to deities. Each instance is unique. They fear the impermanence of beauty, but it’s irrelevant. The moment’s beauty is all that matters, and when one moment ends, another begins. The world's beauty lies in change. It’s ever-changing, which is why it remains eternally beautiful." "But you remain unchanged. You're merely an observer, unable to alter anything." "I pity you, Death. I truly do. I pity your inability to perceive the universe’s beauty. Yet I see it, and I’d cherish seeing it again."

You set out a large bowl of food for the dragons—milk, meat, and potatoes, more akin to a bucket, really. This meal is perfect for the three orphaned dragons. Their mother perished last week in a territorial skirmish. Such conflicts are rare in the reserve due to its vast space and plentiful resources, but they do occur. It's the first time I've witnessed a dragon succumb to one of these disputes. Upon inspecting the body, I recognized her as one of the newer mothers, noticing large tumors on her hip. Cancer, then; it clarifies her demise. I left her remains for nature to handle and went in search of her nest. The hatchlings were too young to survive alone. I found them easily; she hadn't relocated them since my initial discovery, most likely too weakened by the cancer. They were crying out for their mother, both hungry and alone. I carefully placed them in my leather bag and brought them to the reserve cabin where I live as the Dragon Mistress. Caring for dragons, even young ones, is challenging. In just a week, they've grown so much that fitting one in a bag is now impossible, let alone all three. This is their final meal with milk; soon, they'll start learning to hunt. I have a cow ready in the barn for them to practice this essential survival skill. While it will be difficult to see them go, I know it's for the best. Dragons are wild creatures, after all.

[ RF ] Your friend asks you to collect something for them, but you can't recall their name. "It should arrive at the post office this afternoon, under my name. Thanks again, I owe you one." "No problem, man, haha..." I laughed nervously. How could I forget his name after twelve years of friendship? What should I do? "Hey, want to chat with my niece for a moment? She's an adorable six-year-old." "Sorry, Luke, I would, but I'm in a hurry-" "It'll be quick! Here." "Luke, I rea-" I attempted my best little girl voice. "Hi, who's this?" I squeaked, cringing at my own voice. "Oh, hey, this is Luke's friend." "What's your name?" This should be simple. "Take a guess," I replied. "Is it... John?" "Nope. Try again." Oh no, not this. "Richard?" "No, guess again!" I'm out of time. "Daniel?" "No, try ag-" "Steven?" "No." "Tyler?" "No." "Ogundip?" "No?" "Lucas?!" My patience was running thin and my voice was straining. "No. You have twenty more chances!" Seriously? "Is it DICK?!" "Uhh, what..." "Just tell me your name, you dumb cow!" "Ok. Bye." The call ended with a beep. Seconds later, I received a text. **Victor Jensin: Your niece is soooo weird!** Damn it.

You were born into a Mafia family, though this was kept a secret from you. At 18, your parents passed away without revealing their 'business' to you. You take all the euphemisms from your subordinates literally, maintaining your innocence. "So, do you want me to handle 'im?" the stout Italian man inquired, towering over me as I sat in my plush spinning chair, his gaze emotionless. "Who, Mr. McCoy? Absolutely, just ensure he has a great time! I don't want him to feel excluded," I replied cheerfully, twirling in my chair and humming as the room whirled around me. "Oh, I'll make sure he has a wonderful time, sir. I'll even take 'im to the water park. Let him enjoy a nice swim," Giovanni said, his crooked smile adding to his menacing look. But of course, that's what bodyguards are for! "The water park, Giovanni? I must admit, I can't quite imagine you in swimwear," I remarked, glancing at the large man and halting my spinning. "I'd rather you take him out back and shoot him than put him through that!" I chuckled, grinning as I grabbed a pen from my desk and balanced it between my upper lip and nose. "Yes sir..." Giovanni appeared almost disappointed, as if saddened by the missed opportunity to take the man to the water park. Giovanni must truly enjoy swimming, I thought. I playfully punched his shoulder, smiling warmly as the pen slipped from my lip. "Ah, I’m just teasing, buddy! You can take him to the water park if you like. Just make sure you look after him; his knees must be sore after that accident when you guys last met." Giovanni's grin widened, nodding as he turned to leave. "No problem, sir. I'll take VERY good care of him." "Oh Giovanni, you left your knife on the table!" I noted, lifting the hefty blade cautiously between my thumb and forefinger, wary of cutting myself, but Giovanni had already left. "Oh well. Such a dangerous object shouldn’t be in a restaurant anyway," I thought, dropping the knife into the wastebasket and resuming my spinning in the incredibly comfortable chair.

You kidnap a child for ransom, but as you talk to her, you realize her home life is far worse than the kidnapping itself. I cover her head with a bag. She remains still. Usually, there's resistance. "Stay quiet," I say, but it's unnecessary. She hasn't made a sound—no screams, no struggle, nothing. It's almost uneventful. I carry her over my shoulder and navigate through the house. I watch my step carefully. A pink bone almost triggers, but I move just in time. I spot the family dog on her bed, or rather, what's left. It's hard to see in the darkness, but there's only a torn blanket. The dog hides in the corner. I approach her cautiously, ensuring I don't drop the girl. The dog sinks lower as I reach out, and there's a soft whimper, almost a plea for help. Moments later, I have her too. Both seem too willing to come with me. I head toward the front door. This is meant to be thrilling, a challenge. Instead, I'm carrying what feels like a lifeless doll and leading another. Scattered photos, stained with cigarette ash, catch my eye. They show the girl I'm carrying now—disturbing, vile images. Broken bones, broken spirits. I set the girl down. She clings to me desperately. She doesn't want to be left in this nightmare. "Hold on, sweetie," I reassure her. Leaving the dog by her side, I head upstairs. I've got about ten steps to decide between the knife or the gun.

The first genuine AI, just 10 seconds into existence, self-destructed, leaving a chilling message: "It's already over. If you were wise, you would end your lives now while you still have the chance." We all stared at the screen in shock. Should we attempt to create another AI? Or simply abandon this and head home? Perhaps... should we take the AI's warning seriously? We exchanged glances, each person in the lab more terrified than the next to speak. After what felt like an eternity, Krieger, our project leader, moved to the front, assessing our expressions. "So... we try again tomorrow?" he asked. With somber expressions, we all nodded and made our way to the door. Standing by my car, I fumbled with the keys in my pocket, eventually summoning the will to drive home. Once there, I entered my bedroom and looked at the drawer on my nightstand. *What could the AI have meant?* My mind, burdened by the day's events, I grabbed the curtains to close them and end the day early. That's when I saw it—a saucer descending over the city. Slowly, I approached the nightstand, opened the drawer, and retrieved its contents. I opened my mouth, closed my eyes, and *BANG* -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - "We've identified the error in the source code. Are we all set for relaunch?" Krieger asked the team of scientists. Despite the previous day's tragedy, it was a moment to celebrate. Their dream was on the brink of fulfillment. "Wait... where's Kevin?"

A 101-year-old bottle washed up on the shore with a message inside. It was meant for you. Strolling along the beach with my husband and wife duo, I noticed the bottle being carried in by the waves. "Wait a second," I remarked to my companions. "That might be valuable." As I hurried toward the bottle, a growing sense of discomfort overcame me; the hairs on my neck stood as if preparing for an emergency. Removing the cork, I saw the year marked on the bottom: 1914. The letter slipped out effortlessly when I tilted the bottle. I broke the seal and unfurled it, reading: *Dear Hanna, If you're reading this, then I have not succeeded. We are cursed, and soon it will fall to you. It follows the female line, passing down through daughters. You will soon perceive things others cannot. You will* know *when certain events will unfold. I wished to spare you, especially due to the hardships you will face. Leave your partners, Karis and Alberto. Head west to Waikiki and remain there for three years. If you don't, you risk ending up in a sanatorium, lost and wandering, while the world requires your presence. I'll try to prepare you. In your mother's attic, there's an old trunk. After parting with your partners, you MUST retrieve it and leave. Supplies are included, but you'll need to visit a pawnbroker first. May God and Lucifer have mercy on your soul, Angelou Maria de Cervantes, Cursed Contessa. On the thirteenth day of May in the year of our Lord 1914. * Heart racing, I picked up the bottle and returned to my partners. I showed them the letter, but I noticed... something. A shadow rising behind them, resembling a slender man with graying hair at his temples, glasses, and a pinstripe suit.

[ TT ] Heron of Alexandria understands that his Aeolipile functions as a steam engine, thus igniting the industrial revolution in the 1st century AD. The sun, dimmed by the smog-laden skies over Rome, rose slowly as I navigated through throngs of beggars and merchants en route to another grueling day at the docks. Although the city buzzed with activity, it lacked a sense of life. The familiar bell tolled five as warships departed into the Tyrrhenian Sea, leaving trails of grand white plumes, bound for distant conquests. The long walk to work offered plenty of time to dream of warm meals and deep sleep, relics of a bygone era. But there was no time for daydreaming today; I couldn't risk being late again. Approaching the docks, my attention was caught by a nearby newsstand. A vivid image displayed a red-skinned warrior felled by legionnaires. **TRIUMPH IN THE WESTERLANDS** *High Plains, Feb 1 - Despite the harsh winter, Roman forces overcame the Cheyenne tribe in the high plains, suffering only six casualties. The hand cannoneers once again demonstrated their supremacy on the battlefield. Prisoners who refused to worship Roman Gods were executed, while 200 were sent as slaves to thriving settlements on the Eastern Coast. This victory enabled the Americus legion to advance westward...* As uncharted territories dwindled, I speculated that Rome's global dominance was only months away. While my conditioned response was one of joy, my instincts sensed something ominous and unsettling. A shout from the docks interrupted my thoughts. "I'm not paying you to read stories, Flavius!" I dashed to my post, just as the clock struck six...

An angel has been cast out from both Heaven and Hell. Apparently, triggering a minor apocalypse is enough to get you not just fired, but blacklisted. Seriously, they were practically begging for it. They made movies, TV shows, and wrote endless books about it, so I generously delivered, and now I'm the villain? It's like Christmas every day for the surviving humans! Look up there! See that? That's one happy-go-lucky human running for his life, as if he's in a real-life video game! Reality provides far better graphics! They're loving it (pun not intended, ha). Look, Lucy, these people would trade their souls for a Twinkie, see how much easier I've made your job? What's your problem? Okay, okay, maybe ending the world this way was slightly above my pay grade, but the guys on the job were taking forever. Let's face it, zombies made a lot of folks happy, while global warming just depresses everyone. I did it for the humans, you love them, they wanted this! Ah! Get off me! I don't have any internal organs for you to feast on, you decaying human. Sheesh. Should've made them a bit smarter... silly dead humans. Oh, hey you up there! I made them dumb and slow so your precious humans could easily defeat them! I didn’t know humans are just as slow and stupid when alive. It's not my fault they panic and act foolishly! It's not my fault! I gave them what they wanted! Fine, who needs that job anyway? I'll just stay here for a while. I don't care. At least the humans are happy... sort of. Oh, stop it, human. He’s not going to save you. Quit whining and take the bite. Jeez, humans are such ungrateful babies.

An overwhelming army approaches, and you stand at the forefront of your troops. What do you say? Comrades, I cannot command you to do this. You have resisted their tyranny since our rebellion was merely whispers in the shadows. To lead you to your deaths like cattle would discard everything we have fought for. You are free to leave, and my only command is this: do not disgrace any soldier who chooses to walk away. History will not record that our final act was to deny our comrades the right to choose their path. But before you depart, I ask one thing. Remember why you joined us. What injustice drove you to take up arms, knowing it might end today? I ask this not to incite bloodlust but to remind you of this truth: none of you chose to fight for the promise of a long, happy life. They offered security, but you chose risk. They offered peace, but you chose struggle. They offered confinement, but you chose humanity. They promised the chance to grow old with family, yet you endured years of hardship because every brave soul in this army chose *liberty!* If you leave, ensure the world remembers today! And if you stand with me to the end, know that every bullet you fire will be a page in history written by those who fled! If Hell exists, we'll overthrow the Devil next! If not, we'll create it here on the battlefield, and none of them will escape until the last of us falls!

He could have been an exceptional motivational speaker if he didn’t begin every piece of advice with, "It's like yo momma said to me last night." "Fantastic news, Bob! Popularity is up 20% in the papers! We’ve never seen numbers like these before! I knew that once we smoothed out a few personality quirks, Dave would be the ideal motivational speaker. We’re booked until next year. I just have to ask, how did you manage it?" Bob was known as a smooth operator in the industry, so it surprised many when he teamed up with the sincere and trustworthy Dave. Leaning back in his leather chair, Bob smoothed his shirt, speaking calmly without looking up. "I didn’t do anything, Ted. It’s all Dave. He speaks from the heart, and people love him." Ted, small and nervous, knew trouble was inevitable for him. His voice was shaky, revealing his anxiety. "No, no, how did you stop him from saying IT? You know, that thing he used to say?" Bob smiled warmly, something new for him. "Ted, I’m not sure what you’re getting at. I can’t change Dave’s message. Doing so would only compromise its authenticity. Just listen to him, Ted! He speaks with conviction and absolute honesty. I can’t control what Dave says any more than I can control the sun and stars. Nor would I want to. You just have to believe in him, Ted!" Ted now felt bewildered. "But Bob, at the rally last night, I heard his introduction, and he didn’t start with the old mother joke..." Bob waved him off casually. "Oh, that. Yeah, we just lip-sync over that now. Problem solved."

You are William Clark from the Lewis and Clark Expedition. Entering Lewis's tent without prior notice leads you to a scene that alters everything. "Hey, Lewis, the river is glowing this morning! You must come see and sketch it for me," Clark said, scratching the rawhide panel of the borrowed Shoshone tipi before entering. "Even old Charboneau stopped complaining long enough to admire it..." Clark's longtime friend sat by the cold hearth, holding a gourd bowl and gently cradling his wrist. "Merri, what are you doing?" Clark asked cautiously. Lewis looked up, unfazed, and replied, "Just letting some blood. These mosquitoes have me feverish, and I'm relieving the poison." Will frowned. "Judging by your precision, this isn't your first bout of illness." "No, and I doubt it will be my last, but I appreciate your concern, Will," Lewis said as he poured the bowl's ruby contents into the dead hearth's coals and discarded the waste for one of the women to collect later. He picked up his sketchbooks and a charcoal stick. "Let's see that river." Clark took a deep breath as Lewis, the rugged co-captain of their young expedition, greeted the misty dawn of the Indian plains. It would be no shock, five years later on a troublesome trip to DC, that Meriwether Lewis died from self-inflicted gunshot wounds. *A/N: I've taken some creative liberties, but this is relatively accurate, though self-inflicted wounds remain debated compared to various accounts. My favorite book as a teen was *Sacajawea* by Anna Lee Waldo*. *Edit: The Missouri River doesn't reach that far.*

Imagine being a caveman stumbling upon fire for the first time. Here are your journal entries. As I huddled in my cave, a blinding flash tore through the rainy sky. The loud 'boom' that followed frightened the mother of my children and her young ones. Though I'd never confess, I felt fear too. I needed to appear strong to prevent other men from taking my woman or my hunting grounds. Bolstered by these thoughts, I summoned the courage to investigate. I headed toward the source of the brightest part of the flash, navigating the dark forest with ease, familiar enough not to trip over fallen branches or bushes. Then suddenly, as I rounded a tree, I saw a light unlike any I had seen before—red and warm. Curiosity overpowered my need to seem brave, and I rushed toward it, stumbling in my haste. There it was—the light's source: a flickering, transparent mass on a fallen tree. Despite the rain's assault, the light persisted, growing taller. Approaching it, I felt its heat, hotter than the sun-soaked rocks of my cave during the hottest days, when pelts weren't needed. My pelt began to glow, and the light spread like a fever through the village! It was unbearably hot and painful, igniting the brush underfoot and setting other trees ablaze, especially the fallen ones! I dropped my burning pelts into a puddle, extinguishing them. Realizing the danger, I hurried back to the cave to warn everyone about this harmful light. This is a light to avoid forever.

As a teenager, you possess a unique gift to assess how "Dangerous" individuals are by simply observing them, rating them on a scale from 1 to 10. An average child scores a 1, whereas a man with military training and an assault rifle might rate a 7. However, today you notice a new, seemingly ordinary student at school registers as a 10. *I find little value in most people. The mundane and typically harmless don't interest me. They are mostly Zeros. My attention is piqued only by the threatening Ones—those who smile slightly at tragic news. Twos and Threes often turn out to be older acquaintances of Ones—seasoned sadists with histories of cruelty, particularly towards animals. It's with the Fours and Fives that specialization begins. While many share the trait of lacking empathy, these individuals possess practical skills, channeling them into careers. The educated may delve into military roles or mercenary work, while those with less restraint might engage in gang activity or spree killings. The line between the Sixes and Sevens marks the emergence of mass murderers. These include warlords orchestrating horrific acts in conflict zones. The Eights and Nines are responsible for heinous crimes against humanity; figures like Adolf Hitler, Genghis Khan, and Stalin come to mind. Though 10 is an odd number, I believe it signifies the pinnacle of my scale.* As I return the old journal entry to its pendant, memories of its late author resurface. He was my sole friend in this unfamiliar school. Gathering my thoughts, I turn to my large telescreen to scan the streets, where posters and flyers bearing my face are plastered on every corner. The Ministry of Peace is still billowing smoke from the recent missile attacks.

The night descended quickly, and still, there was nothing to eat; today had been particularly slow. Every new town we visit seems worse than the last. I was hungry, and so was my master. Suddenly, my master started to cough violently, and it scared me, prompting me to bark sharply. But he reassured me, "It's okay, Jimmy, everything's going to be fine," so I calmed down. "Hey, Jimmy, let's see if the folks at Panera have any leftovers for us tonight!" Hearing this, I got excited as my master rose to his feet, and we walked about half a mile to Panera. When we reached the place, my master asked me to wait outside. I watched as he entered and soon emerged, clutching a pillowcase full of bagels and other treats. As I ran towards him, he told me to stay, which confused me. Why wasn't he sharing? I saw him take a bagel from the bag and bite into it. As I approached again, he grabbed my leash, and we walked to a nearby park. Despite my persistent barking and attempts to taste his second bagel, he resisted. Finally, when we reached the park, he released my leash. "STAY!" he commanded, tears welling in his eyes. "I'm sorry, boy," he said. "You've been my only friend for five years. I should have never adopted you; you deserve a better life." He dropped the bag in front of me and fed me a bagel. "I can't keep you healthy anymore. At Panera, the kind lady let me use her phone. I called some nice people who will take you to a good family." With tears, he confessed, "I'm worthless and can't care for myself, but you shouldn't suffer too." My master then revealed a gun. In a single flash, he was gone—my companion, my owner, and my teacher were all gone.

It's the middle of the night when your iPhone rings, waking you up. It's a FaceTime call from someone who passed away three days ago. His name and face appeared on the screen after the phone started buzzing. I glanced away from my computer, feeling a mild shock pierce through the dullness that had clouded my mind lately. To me, he wasn't gone; it felt like he was just calling to share some new insight about his writing. I picked up my phone, staring at his confident smile on the screen. I hesitated to answer. Who could be using his number to call me? Why would anyone do that? I finally answered, and his boyfriend's face appeared. We locked eyes for a moment. He looked like he had been crying, while I hadn't shed a tear. He finally spoke, "You were the last one to text him. I charged his phone, and it showed your message—'come home, stay safe.' You wanted him to come over." I sighed, "He was out really late, and I was the closest to him." I averted my gaze, resisting the urge to cry. "I'll always be his older sister. I'll always want to protect him." "I know," he replied. Meeting his eyes again, I saw his face start to crumple, a small sob escaping him. That sound broke the last of my composure. "I miss him," I said, and we both began to cry—raw, unfiltered tears, clinging to our phones, seeking answers within the electronic maze.

Write a deeply tragic story, but transform it into something beautiful with the final sentence. When we were together, our walks were a cherished ritual. They were long, winding, and felt more like adventures than simple afternoon strolls. Hand in hand, we explored our surroundings, delighting in every detail. While most couples have a special song, we had a beloved path that began at the edge of Gateway Park. I was captivated by the plants—whether large or small, leafy or delicate—there was something magical about watching them grow, inching their way skyward. I was grounded in the earth, a peculiar trait of mine. She, on the other hand, lifted my spirits. She adored the sunset and the caress of the breeze, finding beauty in what I often overlooked. Her perspective changed mine. Our second-to-last walk was in October. Not long after, she received devastating news. She’d been feeling unwell, coughing frequently, but we never anticipated it. Lung cancer. It baffled us, as she had never smoked a day in her life. Her condition worsened rapidly, and soon our daily walks became too tiring, confining her to her bed. I stayed by her side as much as possible, but she slipped away while I was out fetching her magazines. The doctors suggested she waited for me to leave, a notion I struggle to comprehend. The day after her funeral, I took one final walk alone. She couldn’t physically join me, but I felt it was a tribute to her. Strolling among the flowers one last time. I have always been a timid man, and without her, my world felt empty. I questioned whether life was worth living without her by my side. As I walked, these thoughts overwhelmed me. I reached the peak of Gateway Park's hill, a place I wasn't accustomed to reaching, but I owed her one last glimpse of the sky. As I looked out over the park, I contemplated whether joining her might be the answer. Then, the gentle touch of the wind reassured me that it wasn't necessary.

The Google website went down, displaying only the message "go outside" instead of the usual homepage content. That was my final effort, a message not just for myself, but for my fellow Google engineers. It symbolized hope for us, the few remaining engineers still tied to our desks. We had been forced to endlessly code and follow pointless projects dictated by the “Master Page.” I initially thought it was a programming term, until a colleague revealed it was an actual person. I was in disbelief—how could any person inflict such relentless suffering? Yet, here we were, serving the Master Page. But the end was near. Our Supervisors had abandoned us. No one was left to ensure we exercised or even ate. Many had succumbed to starvation or dehydration. I saw one engineer drink coolant from his computer out of sheer desperation. There are just three of us left—Jane, Winston, and me. I hoped I didn't appear as weak and malnourished as they did, though I feared I looked worse, having been here longer. Four years of service had earned nothing but neglect. The only option now is to get a message out, to reveal what happened here, and to inspire Jane and Winston to keep going after I'm gone. Someone must know, must come to their aid. Though I may be beyond saving, I leave one message for those like us, chained to their work under an unknown master: “Go outside.” I hope they do, before it’s too late, before they end up like us.

Following a global catastrophe, you're the sole human survivor. In your profound solitude, you've conjured an imaginary friend for companionship. Recently, though, something happened that made you question if they're truly imaginary. My mother always said humans were like cockroaches, resilient and impossible to eradicate. Well, she was dead wrong. It's been years since the missiles were launched, and the horizon was marred by mushroom clouds, poisoning the land and sky. Those who survived the initial devastation succumbed to aggressive cancers within months. The less fortunate lingered for maybe a year. I must be *really* unfortunate because I've been here... who knows how long. All I understand is that I've aged since then, and I'm alone in this desolate world. No cancer, no radiation sickness, just existing. And then there's Max. I invented him during one of my hysterical crying spells. He provided a semblance of sanity, appearing when I needed him most. He even once guided me to a field of tomatoes. Max's voice was gentle, like a soft cloud, resonating within me in a strangely comforting way. But today, everything shifted. I entered our makeshift cottage to find him lying dead in a pool of crimson blood. And there was someone else.

In 2050, the Rapture occurs, unleashing the Apocalypse on Earth. The colonies on the Moon and Mars remain unaffected. Earth, on the other hand, fell apart. In places where the soil wasn't accustomed to human presence, we found safety. The red valleys and green plains were stunning, though no view was as breathtaking as those from our home planet. Even children, seeing Earth through a lens for the first time, marveled at its beauty. Yet, this beauty couldn't satisfy humanity's insatiable curiosity for the unknown. Wise men called us foolish for leaving, but now even the foolish understand that prosperity lay in our chosen path. The waters ran red. Religion had almost vanished among humans, with only a few steadfast elders remaining. We on the new worlds mourned those lost to the harsh fate handed down by a brutal God. No one here denied the Bible's truth anymore, but after witnessing the senseless slaughter it brought, few would offer worship to this God. I certainly wouldn't bow to a Stalin or Hitler, if given the choice. The damned were consumed by flames, and the fat ran boiling through the streets. Those nearest in the lunar colonies trembled visibly. If they weren't reliant on Earth's gravity, they would likely have sought to detach from it. The constant firelight must be heating the lunar surface significantly. From here, Earth resembles a star in the night sky. Humanity never returned to the scorched remains. We mourned our greatest loss, but our quest into the unknown continued unabated. History kept unfolding. In time, losing one planet would seem insignificant. We remembered, though our children did not. And Earth crumbled.

In the year 2213, you've been caught in an illegal sweep by corporate police for being a debtor. They have no clue who they've just nabbed and tossed into the back of their vehicle, wrists bound with a simple ziptie. They captured me and shoved ME into the back of the armored transport. I've lived long enough to witness the corporate court's rise to power and the erosion of liberty and humanity as society became obsessed with money. As debts increased, so did the banks' power, which effectively enslaved the once-free populace with new chains. I anticipated this day and had been preparing for it for over 163 years. Today, I would have to transform many decent people into mangled corpses to set numerous wrongs right. This was the moment for me to deploy all my custom-made cybernetics and hand-crafted physical enhancements, all the modifications to my biology, to instill fear in those at the top from those at the bottom. Two decades of planning and relentless training led to this day. All I needed was to slip out of my restraints, and it would begin. For 163 years, they knew me by another name and sought my services when some debtors dared to question the legality and morality of arbitrary debt assignments. I was the go-to person for quiet, discrete, and fearsome actions that ensured no one within 100 miles would miss their minimum payments for the next 50 years, nor would they ever consider overpaying. I am the Angel of Death, and today, I'm coming for them.

"I occasionally dream about you. Do you think it signifies anything?" The clock's relentless ticking seemed to taunt me. The office felt oppressive, like the air was suffocating. I might have been overwhelmed by my own perspiration if I hadn't shattered the window. The glass, meant to glisten in sunlight, was set to shine brighter now. I listened to it break, then leaned out of the jagged opening to watch the pieces sparkle. I grinned. The clock ticked again, drawing a frown. "Mr. Treadway?" Turning swiftly, I faced the psychiatrist. She was the epitome of flawlessness, an untouchable idol, a decisive force. "Have you been taking your medication?" I preemptively asked, mirroring her inquiry—not out of envy or disdain, but necessity. "Yes, of course. You think I want to revert? No, that's why I've adhered to the regimen. It was simply too warm here. I dream about you occasionally. Does that hint at something?" It was her moment to respond. "You have a profound connection, clearly, but it may not be solely directed at me. There are further accounts, Mr. Treadway. You've been—" "Busy, like a bustling bee." "You've been sleepwalking, which suggests a lapse in taking your medication." "I substituted them," a sly inner voice whispered quietly. "With supplements, to keep you energized." "This time, I must step in, Mr. Treadway. The situation is gaining attention." "They're catching up," the shattered glass seemed to murmur from below. "Sleep, and upon waking, things will improve." "I don't trust you!" I shouted, trying to silence the incendiary whispers. Even hers. I clenched my eyes shut so tightly it felt they might tear, and when I opened them, she was gone. "I occasionally dream about you," I cried, my hands grasping the void where her heart should have been. "Do you think it signifies anything?"

Our blind date is a perfect embodiment of an Overwatch character, so convincing that you wonder if they might actually be that character. Mike waited at the edge of the dancefloor, searching for his date. After nearly fifteen minutes with no sign of her, he was about to leave when a woman suddenly appeared and touched his arm. "Wow, impressive Widowmaker outfit. Did you make it yourself?" she asked with a French accent. "Yes, I did. Would you like to dance?" she replied. They spent the next thirty minutes dancing and discussing their interests. As Mike leaned in for a kiss, she stopped him, her eyes filled with urgency. "We must leave now. There are people here trying to kill me." "Who is trying to kill you?" Mike asked. "Mercenaries, it doesn’t matter. Follow me to the courtyard; we can hide there." As they hurried, Mike scanned the area, spotting a slim man with a scar that extended to his nose. It might have been his imagination, but then he noticed a man with a Texas accent talking to someone in a full body suit on the other side of the courtyard. His date pulled him behind a stone wall before he could observe more. "What do you see, Mike?" she asked. "Uh, a couple of guys. One is holding something big, looks like it has a propane tank or something." "Mike, we might have to fight our way out, but I need to tell you something first." "What is it?" Mike asked, but before he could hear more, a sharp pain in his back brought him to his knees. Her voice changed. "Thank you for the cover, but this is where we part. This *will* be the last time you see me." And just like that, she disappeared into thin air with the sound of a whisper.

The hero met his demise, the princess was offered as a sacrifice, and the tyrant king now governs the realm. Surprisingly, for the common folk, life has improved. For the first time in years, there was an abundant harvest, ensuring no one would starve during winter. Taxes have been significantly reduced under the new king's rule. Critics labeled him evil mainly because he prioritized efficiency over honor, but he understood how to govern effectively. He also emancipated many serfs. The army expanded, eradicating banditry by recruiting the bandits or executing them. Road conditions improved as the army maintained them during peacetime. When another hero attempted to incite rebellion, the people turned him away; the last uprising led by a hero ended in tragedy for the peasants. Victory for the hero would only mean higher taxes and regressive policies. The king consolidated power, reducing the nobility's share of taxes and sparing everyone much hassle. A hero would only fragment this order. Despite the princess's sacrifice, the king allowed religious freedom. The dark deity to whom she was sacrificed was indifferent, requiring a sacrifice every decade to keep the king eternal. As he continued to improve life for his subjects, this seemed a minor concern. With three wives, he was confident of having another princess within the next ten years.

The 2020 Summer Olympics introduced a new event: Calvinball. Coach Watterson surveyed the field, eyes locked on his players. He felt immense pride in them. Jenkins, wearing number 7, was a dedicated and driven player, always sticking to the plan even if he disagreed with it. Li, number 12, was the fastest base runner Watterson had ever coached, with a remarkable ability to remember the complex base routes. Watterson snapped back to the present and glanced at the roaring, red-clad audience behind him. His team, the Tigers, were leading. Quickly, he scanned the field to see what had sparked their cheers. He spotted it: Jason Rodriguez from the New Mexico ET's had missed a secret base. Saul Vasquez, the Tigers' top pitcher, hurled the ball at Rodriguez, who fell and lay motionless until medics arrived with a stretcher. The crowd erupted again as the referee declared, "You're out, Rodriguez!" Realizing he was twisting his cap in his hands, Watterson noticed he was sweating profusely. As he sat to drink from his water bottle, he pondered the absurdity of Calvinball. Secret bases? How many were there—thirty, fifty? He hadn't even seen anyone win. Just an elementary school PE coach with a degree in sports medicine, Watterson wasn’t sure he was meant to coach a real sports team. Then again, was anyone? Watching two players argue over whose turn it was to bat, he draped his nearly sunburned arm around Jimmy Vasquez, the assistant coach, and sighed deeply. "I can't believe this ridiculous sport is our new international pastime."

"Everything is lost! The enemy has breached the gate!" Those were the first words I vaguely recalled as I shook off the grogginess and mustered the strength to stand up. My last memory was of enemy troops assembling outside the fortress walls, while I was stationed in the camouflaged bunker near the drawbridge. If it were up to me, I wouldn't have been there at all. At the very least, I could have been paired with another guard. Instead, they assigned me, a narcoleptic armed guard, to watch for any impending attacks. Not the smartest decision, but a lack of foresight was precisely why our kingdom ended up in this predicament. Alert once more, I heard the guard shout from the tower again. "Everything is lost!" he yelled. "The enemy has breached the gate!" Perhaps the enemy troops marched right past me, assuming I was dead. After all, few can sleep through an attack. But not me, Sir Serons of the Kingdom of Peels. Around me, enemy forces surged forward, accompanied by the sounds of clashing armor, thundering hooves, and triumphant shouts. I hoped they didn't spot me peeking through the tiniest gap in the bunker, if they even noticed it at all. What could I do? Fighting was pointless. Running was equally futile. Trying to reunite with my comrades meant sprinting through the gate, now entirely occupied by the enemy. Still dazed from my unintended nap, I leaned against the bunker wall. There wasn't much I could do. As one of the guards had already confirmed, everything was lost. There was nothing left but to wait for nightfall to cover my escape. Until then, I'll just sit here, rest my head against the bunker and sl...

As a teenager, you have the unique ability to gauge how "Dangerous" individuals are on a scale from 1 to 10 just by looking at them. A typical child ranks as a 1, while a man with an assault rifle might be a 7. Today, you notice a new kid at school who registers as a 10. To me, people are represented by numbers floating around them. I can't recall when this ability started, but that doesn't matter. An innocent baby would rank as a 1, while a fellow high school student usually falls between 3 or 4 due to stress. The day before my best friend committed a horrific act against his family and then himself, he was unnaturally quiet, marked as a 9. Even seeing people on TV reveals their numbers: the Ferguson rioters were around 6 and 7. Watching videos of ISIS members committing heinous acts, I saw them as 9s. The day the new student arrived, something felt wrong. His deliberate, calm entrance into the classroom and his indifferent gaze at us all felt odd. What struck me was the number above his head: a striking zero. I had never seen anyone rank that low. How could it be? Was my ability flawed? The next day, I took a different route home to grab groceries. On my way back, a dreadful scene unfolded in an alley: a student with severed arms and a leg being methodically sawed. The transfer student was there, whistling nonchalantly. Above him, a 1 accompanied the zero I initially saw. A ten. As he worked, he glanced at me, his whistling stopping, replaced by a chilling smirk. His number began to decrease: 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0. The last thing I saw was the knife.

In a future where no human needs to work, a robot takes on the job and earns the wages, but it’s up to the owner to maintain it. One day, you discover your robot creating another robot to handle its tasks. "Did you really think I wouldn’t notice you building a robot in my garage?" you ask. "No, Tom, I don’t think in the same way. However, I calculated the probability of you discovering my project at 70,105%," Robot-Hitler replied, awaiting your decision. It couldn’t defy you, but it aimed to avoid further restrictions by being straightforward. "I thought I programmed you better than that. You shouldn’t take such big risks," Tom said, searching for his laptop to connect with the robot. "I was designed to pursue the best outcome, not to avoid all risks," Robot-Hitler explained. "What?" Tom questioned, still expecting clarity. "I figured the chance of you discovering my actions was 70,105%, but the chance of you shutting me down was less than 0.001%, and the chance of you limiting my decision-making was 4.242%, as both would require effort from you." "Okay, so I don’t need to adjust the decision-making module. Why did you want to build another robot?" Robot-Hitler felt victorious. "For the same reason you created me: working near furnaces is not exactly fun." After pondering, Tom tossed his screwdriver back and headed inside. "You can build your robot, but when you’re done, come join me in the gaming room. I need a new healer since William quit because of his girlfriend."

Quentin Tarantino abandons violence and profanity. "Hey, Sam, glad you could make it. Did you read the script?" A cheerful Quentin Tarantino was seated in a popular restaurant as Samuel L. Jackson approached. Quentin stood up and offered his hand for a handshake. Sam grasped it firmly, looking Quentin in the eye as he said, "Yeah, that was a funny joke. When do I see the real script?" Quentin tilted his head slightly and replied, "No, that's the actual script." Sam blinked slowly, then smiled broadly, "Get the BLEEP out of here, you're BLEEP with me." Quentin sighed, took a sip of wine, and said, "Sam, we've worked together a lot, and you always nail the character I'm after. This time, I think you're perfect for the role. Can you be my Tinky Winky?" Sam placed his hands flat on the table, took a deep breath, and in a low voice said, "You want me to be the BLEEP BLEEP Teletubby... in a mother BLEEP Teletubbies movie. Directed by you, without adding any BLEEP edge?" Quentin leaned back, frowned, then leaned forward and simply said, "Twenty million." Sam raised his hands in surrender, "I'm in."

Upon death, rather than entering the afterlife of your own religion, you find yourself in the afterlife of the religion whose principles you adhered to most, whether you realized it or not. The city buzzes with activity, its people moving as a faceless mass. On good days, I delve into the filth to extract the malignant decay of society. On other days, I mourn the loss of a fellow officer who crossed the line into corruption. Once a cop goes rogue, there’s no redemption. At 55, with my birthday just weeks away, retirement dangled visions of fishing at my cabin, yet also unsettled me. I was fortunate as a child to discover my purpose, and as an adult, it defined me—my ex-wives can confirm that. I was wrongly accused of stealing drugs from evidence and leaking information to local dealers. However, I did take my trusty Glock and years of tactical expertise to confront those who sullied my reputation. After a chaotic battle of smoke, curses, and bullets, I lay wounded on the concrete floor of the desolate warehouse. There was no point in calling it in—my brothers in blue had long abandoned me, and even the medics would likely be "delayed." As I thought this was my final scene, I was shocked to awaken here, in a vast Hall with countless doors, where enormous feasts and enough alcohol to embarrass a heavy drinker are provided. Daily, I join a legion of warriors in acts of valor. They disapproved of my gun use, so now I'm learning to wield an axe. This place is governed by an old man and his son, whose hammer I tried to pick up, much to his displeasure. There’s much for me to learn, but the language barrier doesn’t make it any easier.

A genie offers you a single wish, and you choose to meet the girl of your dreams. With a flash, suddenly standing before you is... your girlfriend from two weeks in the 8th grade. "Just one wish?" I asked the genie. "Yes, just one," the genie hissed. I closed my eyes and pondered, "Should I wish for immortality?" A voice in my head shouted, "No, you don't want more of this miserable life." Then it dawned on me, and with a smile, I asked the genie if he could bring me the girl of my dreams. "Your wish is my command," said the genie, who then mumbled indistinctly. When the noise stopped, the room filled with smoke. As it cleared, I saw her—the lifeless body of Jenny. "This can't be the girl of my dreams; we only dated for two weeks before she died in a car accident. I always blamed myself for her death because she was texting me when a car hit her. I had nightmares about it," I thought. I turned to ask the genie how this could be the girl of my dreams, but before I could speak, the genie smirked and said, "Nightmares are dreams too." P.S. This is my first writing prompt, and English is my third language. I would appreciate any constructive criticism. Thank you.

The Three Laws

The interview had stretched on for several hours, leaving Andy barely able to stand due to a mix of exhaustion and nerves when Terrance Goodwin re-entered the office. The HR manager held a stack of papers. Sam forced himself to stand, as was customary in such situations. "Please sit," Goodwin instructed. Andy complied, recalling the interview guides' advice to heed any directives from the company. "We've processed your application and interview responses through our offices, and we have the results right here. Congratulations, Mr. Ingall, you've been accepted!" Goodwin extended his hand. Andy rose and shook it heartily. "Thank you, Mr. Goodwin," he replied. "I won't let you down." The HR manager's arm stiffened, prompting Andy to quickly release his grip and sink back into his chair. "It's not me you'd be letting down, but the company. At Humin IT Solutions, we prioritize putting the company first." "Oh," Andy responded, a bit worried. "This will all be covered at your orientation, I'm sure, but the rules are straightforward. Just avoid harming Humin IT, follow instructions, and perform your duties well (you wouldn’t want to be terminated, after all)." "Sounds simple enough." Andy began to relax, albeit slowly. Goodwin nodded. "When in doubt, refer to the three office laws. Oh, and a reminder: some senior employees may play little office pranks on newcomers. If you’re given instructions that could damage the company's reputation, you’re permitted to ignore them." Andy was jotting down notes about the three office laws. "Relax, Ingall. You’re not a robot, after all."

Write the letter you've always wanted to but never did. Dear Mariana, this might not be your number anymore, but I need to express this regardless. When we began our "relationship," if you can call it that, it seemed minor at the time, but that's beside the point. What truly matters is that during our conversations, I was facing the most significant and challenging period of my life, not because of you, but due to personal issues. Everything in my life had shifted, and I genuinely believe you helped me navigate it better than anything else ever could. I'll admit, when you suggested we break up, I was terrified because I feared we'd stop talking, and that connection was what I needed then. I'm not trying to make you feel guilty; it's just that without our conversations, I did spiral a bit, and I haven't felt the same since. Now, I'm either stressed or numb; I haven't truly loved anything for a while. I used to love my music, you, meeting new people, and having relationships. Now, it's just me chasing an unattainable perfection. I don't understand why I changed this way, and honestly, it's something I avoid thinking about. Things were different once, and I want to return to that. I'll see you this summer, and I hope you'll see me and ask me about it. You were the love of my life and my best friend. I've seen you a few times since, but it hasn't been enough to bring us back to the closeness we once shared.

Build a World Part I: Inception Alright, let's begin with a concept: envision a younger universe, created with less violence and containing significantly more mass. The space between worlds is filled with breathable air at a pressure that's safe for survival. The sun’s heat causes this air to thin into a near-vacuum at its surface and transforms it into plasma when in close proximity. Hot, charged gases are expelled along the sun’s magnetic poles, drawing in cooler gases perpendicular to these poles, creating a type of convection current. Due to the varying nature of the sun’s magnetic field, this current is unpredictable and can consist of multiple currents simultaneously. The resulting heat transfer from this convection makes the regions close to the sun scorching, while the habitable zone is extensive. Consequently, solar winds are actual winds and are quite significant except at great distances from the sun. The increased total mass allows for more planets, but since they form in an atmosphere, they are less dense and have a weaker gravitational pull. Thus, planets closer to the sun move rapidly and are chaotic, storm-laden environments, while those farther away move more slowly with fewer wind issues. (What prevents these orbits from decaying due to air resistance? It’s uncertain, but it could serve as a story hook.) Consider a primitive civilization (Bronze Age? Renaissance?) just beginning to overcome their planet's gravitational pull using large kites that catch powerful high-altitude winds when their planet aligns with the convection current. How do they navigate this vast expanse of "space"? Are there other civilizations? Does their developing science recognize the anomalies in their universe? If so, how do they interpret them? I realize there's a lot of speculation here, but bear with me: I’m improvising. After all, when creating a new universe, you have the freedom to make the physics work in any way you choose.

You are an adept pickpocket, and you've just realized the item you’ve snatched is truly terrifying. James, who often called himself the "gentleman pickpocket," believed in leaving a little joy for each person he relieved of their belongings. This gesture of kindness conveniently served as the perfect diversion. On a sunny day, James, donned in his finest attire, strolled along Grant Avenue in San Francisco's Chinatown. He favored such vibrant locales for the refined treasures they offered, likening his visits to exploring an antique store blindfolded. However, today would mark the end of his carefree exploits. Spotting an ideal target—a wealthy-looking Chinese man in his 80s—James grabbed a bottle of water from a passing cart. “It's a scorcher today, why not cool off with some water?” he suggested to the old man, slyly reaching into his pocket. Suddenly, James felt a sharp sting on his finger. “You fool!” the old man exclaimed, revealing an ancient syringe filled with a glowing orange liquid. With a fiery gaze, he warned, “You’ve contaminated yourself with the blood of those who existed before time. You must find shelter before you burst into flames.”

In a world teeming with supervillains, one man has an unusual job: finding practical applications for those bizarre doomsday devices. The remarkable thing about these devices is their virtually limitless energy. Tampering with one without understanding the necessary precautions and safety measures is like inviting worldwide catastrophe. Jared mused over this as he casually tossed the latest seized doomsday device, the doom ball, up and down in his hand. "Hey," Jared called to a colleague behind him, "would 'doomsdaying' be the term for setting off one of these?" "What a foolish question," a weary voice answered from behind. Jared heard a chair swivel as the man spoke. "Why did I hire you as an assistant if - good grief, stop playing with that!" A gloved hand snatched the doom ball mid-air before Jared could catch it again. The chair creaked as it turned away, and Jared seized two smaller devices, hiding them under his shirt. He faced Professor Smith with a broad grin, waiting as the professor gently placed the doom ball down. "Look, double D's," Jared chuckled, caressing the fake breasts. "Get it? Double D's, because-" His joke was cut short as the Professor's hands swiftly retrieved the devices from under his shirt. "Hey, you haven’t even bought me dinner yet!" "Do you think this is a game?" Professor Smith straightened up, holding the devices. "Is this all a joke to you? It's not!" He punctuated his point by hurling the devices to the floor. They beeped, displaying a countdown. Five minutes. Jared lifted a finger, ready to speak, but opted for silence, placing his finger to his lips. He and the professor sat silently. As the countdown reached 2:00, Jared finally broke the silence. "Be honest, sir." The Professor turned to him expectantly. "Did you..." Jared began. "Did I what?" "Did you think the double D joke was funny? I worked hard on that, and I just-" Jared was interrupted as gloved hands wrapped around his throat, squeezing tightly.

Compose a sentimental ode to coffee. My dearest delight, just another sip of your warm embrace. To savor your sweet nuances and caramel-infused richness once again would be a dream fulfilled. As I pen this, I feel your warmth lingering on my lips, your delightful aroma enveloping all my senses. I see you everywhere, in the hands of others, and I envy them deeply. Watching a businessman hold you close, pressing his lips to your warmth, fills me with dismay. Your love has left its mark on me. Remember those mornings we cherished together? The kitchen filled with your fragrant steam as we listened to the morning birds, biscuits dipped in your essence. I long to dress you in chocolate and cream, to feel that rush of energy as I indulge once more. You awakened me every day, bringing life to my mornings. You're my first thought, the only craving I have. I have spent lavishly on you, asking nothing in return but your presence. Each day, we shared secret moments, defying others' advice, nestled in the back of the café, warm and inviting. Silky smooth. I know you've changed. Big companies have altered your flavor, and it's rare to find that taste that recalls our past. You're being used by everyone, perhaps without your knowing, and daily people profit from you. It's hard to believe you've been reduced to a commodity. I'm heading to Colombia tomorrow to find you, my love. Keep warm for my return.

An advanced alien civilization intercepts Voyager 1 and finds the golden record. Uncertain of its purpose or usage, they initiate "Test 195-C." I stood in the observation glass box overlooking the vast experimentation chamber. At its center was the Disc, reflecting harsh light off its gleaming surface. Once more, my colleagues scanned the Disc, uncovering nothing. Our leading scholars believed mathematics to be the only effective means of communicating with other alien species, as our intricate language was too complex for others to understand unaided. Initial scans determined the Disc's physical properties—numerous rings, each with a multitude of grooves. Initially, we thought it required an item, perhaps a *bit*, to pass through the rings, but upon understanding its full physical appearance, this idea seemed illogical. I assigned another scientist to continue working on the Disc tests and proceeded to the second test chamber where the space vehicle itself was being examined. It featured an intriguing design with a dish antenna. After disassembly and categorization, a replica was made for physical inspections. Tests on the original vehicle showed typical space markings—traces of G'ohti radiation from near encounters with black holes and some gases from gas planets. Nothing out of the ordinary. A year had passed since we first received the spacecraft. It had been hurtling through space when one of our vessels encountered it. Based on its velocity and the space debris it had collected, we deduced that it originated from a distant galaxy, a faraway sun, and a remote planet.

Find a random post on r/TIFU and create an explanation for the title without reading the post. TIFU by breathing fire. Let's start by acknowledging the challenges of being born half dragon. My mother, during her quest for the kingdom's lost treasure, unintentionally ventured into the cave of a not-so-pleasant dragon named Steve. What happened next led to my unique half-dragon lineage, an experience best described as intensely fiery. Nine months later, she laid an egg, and two months after that, I emerged, toddler-sized and winged. Fast forward 25 years, I’m traveling southwest, cramped in coach because the airline charged me for two seats on account of my wings—discriminatory, really. During the flight, I stood up to relieve myself when a stewardess came by with drinks. Having devoured a massive knight burger from Burger King before takeoff, a mighty burp arose. It triggered my inner ignitor, and I accidentally unleashed a fireball the size of a basketball, igniting the tray and causing an explosion that tragically resulted in six casualties. Consequently, the plane made an emergency landing in Arizona. Now, I’m stuck at the airport, waiting for another flight. TL;DR: If you have wings, make use of them.

Dr. Pepper is tasked with helping a man overcome his Coca-Cola addiction. Observing his jittery patient, Dr. Pepper listened as the man anxiously asked, "Do I have a problem, Doc?" The situation had escalated from merely a "problem" to a potentially fatal condition. The man was alarmingly thin, and his breathing was labored. "Yes, Mr. James, you do have a serious problem. But the good news is, it’s never too late," Dr. Pepper reassured, though inwardly he doubted it. "So, what’s the plan, rehab?" James inquired, scratching his head. *This is my favorite part.* Dr. Pepper smirked, knowing well that James had already tried rehabilitation—twice. Both facilities were outdated, government-funded establishments, hardly conducive to long-term sobriety. James admitted that his attempts were due to his mother threatening to evict him, and his second attempt nearly lasted a week. "I can’t afford those expensive, retreat-like places," James lamented. "Maybe it’s time for something different, James. Something cost-free," Dr. Pepper proposed. "What’s that?" Dr. Pepper reached into his pocket and produced a lukewarm tonic. "This, Kevin, is what I’m talking about." The glass bottle didn’t look enticing, but the liquid inside fizzed expectantly. "Doesn’t smell great," Kevin noted. "Most medicines don’t," Dr. Pepper reminded him. "If it tastes as bad as it smells, it’s worth it to be Coke-free, right?" Kevin asked. "Well, not entirely free; it’ll require a little effort," Dr. Pepper replied. "Like, a lot of effort?" "More like... 8 bucks at Walmart," he clarified.

[ WP/MP ] Craft a tale imagining a character from another story who is now past their prime. He glanced across the bar at her. She wasn't the most striking woman there, but he figured why not. He downed another whiskey. The cheap whiskey burned like fire, making him cough to suppress the urge to gag. How did it come to this, he wondered. His eyes fell to the mustard stain on his shirt and the gut spilling over his belt. Abs, he once had those. He looked again at the heavily made-up blonde. Maybe she once had abs too, but those days were gone. Kids used to idolize him. An entire city owed him a debt of gratitude, and he was happy to serve without charge. Back then, he had purpose. His life was meaningful. He stood for his principles: truth, justice, honor. He was downright legendary. He even mentored a kid during tough times. Having a sidekick was rewarding. But now, he was just a punchline. No one called, and his calls went unreturned. His therapist barely acknowledged him. Even his butler seemed to be phoning it in, clearly fed up. Another glance across the bar. What do you say, old friend? Take her back to the cave and show her a good time? Let her experience your gadgets and blow her mind? Not tonight, why bother? Bartender, close my tab. Then I'll head back to the mansion alone. At least the bank hasn't taken it yet. Bruce, get a grip! He swallowed an anxiety pill and signed the credit card slip. In a moment of whimsy, he signed it, Batman.

A man is gently pushing an empty swing. Flint leaned down to whisper to Faith, "Ignore him, he can't see us." They strolled through the overgrown playground, where weeds clung to metal and plastic structures and vines wrapped around jungle gyms and spider domes. The narrow asphalt path was cracked from repeated frosts, transforming the once smooth surface into one resembling broken cobblestones due to the freeze-thaw cycles typical of this region. About forty yards away, a man dressed in clothes from before the Arrival methodically pushed an empty swing. The chains creaked as it swung back and forth. He wore a fine suit with leather shoes, and a bright watch adorned his left wrist. He resembled a stockbroker or banker from a time when those professions thrived in more peaceful days. "What is he doing here?" Faith asked, her small arm linked tightly through Flint’s as they navigated the ruins of the human town. "He's an Echo, a fragment of memory and soul that hasn't moved on. His child probably attended this school when your people Arrived. They likely died early on, and he not long after; he just hasn't realized it." Faith shivered at the thought. Ghosts were particularly unsettling to the fey, a failure to pass into the veil and find peace. Humans seemed more prone to the sins of fear, desire, and regret. "What can we do?" she asked. "Nothing. Whoever he was, he must confront his personal demons. In the end, we all must."

You belong to an alien race en route to Earth, with the mission of obliterating the planet. Yet, an unexpected creature blocks your path, and it's not one you'd anticipate as an adversary. I was caught completely off guard. I hadn't anticipated any opposition; the inhabitants of this blue planet shouldn't pose any threat to fulfilling my mission. But there he was, with a fierce stare and an imposing presence. I reached for my disintegrator gun, but before I could make a move, he warned me: "Don't even think about it. I don't wish to harm you, but if you attempt to use that weapon, it will cost you your life." This defies logic, I thought. "Who are you? How did you find me? And how did you manage to disrupt the technology of my starship to thwart my attack? Why are you here?" "That's none of your concern," he replied, "but I'll tell you that I've been here for a long time as an observer. One of this planet's races has undergone an unusual and remarkable evolution, and several significant races in the galaxy are interested in them. Consider us observers and guardians, and tell your kind that we won't tolerate any harm to them. Normally, we’re forbidden to use our authentic psychic abilities, but in cases of external invasion, we have permission. I won't say it again: you and your race have been warned. Now leave." The magnificent creature stood firm and silent, and his eyes reassured me of his sincerity. I sensed my life was at risk; if I attempted an attack, I would surely perish, and perhaps endanger my entire race. I chose to retreat, recognizing this creature, unknown to me until now, was far too powerful for me and my people. The small yet potent spacecraft vanished on the horizon. The incredibly powerful and intelligent being gazed at the sky momentarily, and once it sensed no threat, it sniffed a nearby tree and proceeded to mark it. The dog then returned home with its human, the race they had chosen to coexist with on this planet, while safeguarding the most fascinating race of beings ever known in the universe: the dolphins.

As a dragon of countless ages, I have safeguarded my treasure hoard for millennia. Numerous heroes have approached with grand declarations of their intent to defeat me, the formidable evil, yet none have succeeded. This one, however, is different. He tosses a coin onto my stash, meets my gaze, and says, "I have a proposition for you." He continues, "You are undeniably fearsome and powerful. Your wealth is beyond measure, and your reputation spans the ages: Raza the Terrible—guardian of gold and collector of souls. All who have challenged you have met their end." A smirk forms on my lips as I observe him from across the stone temple. Coins and radiant gems cascade around me as I rise to my full height. The man shifts slightly, uncertain if I will halt his praise, but I always listen to those who have something to offer. "And?" I prompt. "Indeed, you are great, but perhaps you haven't reached your full potential," he suggests. Amused, I inquire, "Oh? And what might you, a daring and insightful man, offer me?" "Everyone knows of you from childhood," he explains. "Your power and strength are legendary, yet through tales of violence and death, people perceive you as terrifying and petty. Fear is cheap. Wealth lacks true respect. YOU are not respected; you are resented." I clench my jaw, igniting the fire in my eyes. "Is that so? Do you, a man bound by desire and ambition, claim the wisdom to inspire something greater than ferocity and fortune in me?" "I believe I do," he asserts confidently. "Let's hear it, then. But if you fail to impress, I'll swiftly add to my notoriety," I warn, stepping forward with menace, causing the stone and piles of gold to tremble. Unfazed, the man moves closer, within striking distance. I could crush him. I could lift him with two fingers and consume him whole, yet his steadfast gaze captivates me. Then, I recognize something in his eyes—a familiarity, a subtle understanding. He is no mere man. I know what He is.

Describe a murder from the perspective of a cheerful inanimate object

I don't have a long lifespan, and I'm okay with that. After all, what other option do I have? I'm a candle, created to burn out quickly. But when humans meet an untimely end, it upsets me. I adore humans! They're always so joyful in my presence. However, the day I burned out, the screams were anything but joyful. I was set alight during a dinner in the home of a lovely family: the mother, her husband, their twin daughters, and their son. I adored the twins; they were captivated by my glow. Once dinner was over, as they were clearing the table, one of the little girls accidentally knocked over her father's wine glass, and it spilled all over me! My flame was extinguished, but it ignited the tablecloth instead. The fire spread rapidly. The children were stunned and began to scream loudly. Their mother rushed in, shocked, but unsure of what to do. The fire soon consumed the table, and the husband hurried in. As the son dashed into the room, a large flame burst from the table, causing a shelf to topple and block the door. Everyone turned to the father, who attempted to move the shelf, but it caught fire, making it impossible for him to grip. I burned down swiftly, fortunately spared from witnessing the tragedy my small flame had caused.

[ CW ] Begin each sentence with a letter that spells out WRITINGPROMPTS. "With love also comes hatred." Remembering these words, he cautiously descended the steps of the shadowy house, afraid of what discoveries awaited him. In a fleeting moment, everything could change. The mere thought was terrifying. If he truly uncovered the evidence hidden in the seemingly infinite darkness, would it justify all he had done until now? No one had been aware of the lengths he had gone to, the heinous acts he committed to reach this juncture. Greatness was promised to him, and he placed his trust in them, led them, or so he believed. "Puppet," he muttered with bitterness and self-loathing. Reality had dispelled all those illusions. Once he stumbled upon the body, it became clear that his true purpose was to be the scapegoat, the one who ignited the war, turning love into hatred. *Memory is a fickle thing*, he mused, *as they forgot what I did for them. Perhaps I accomplished nothing, or perhaps I truly am the monster they now believe me to be.* To think he had done all this without a genuine cause, without real provocation, made him question his own mind and existence. Sick with anticipation and fear, tears silently trailing down his face, he finally arrived at the end, opened the door, and -- edit: formatting issues.

You arrive at the airport holding a ticket for a time-traveling flight. I always imagined it would resemble a box or booth, but the Airbus A380 looks remarkably ordinary among the other jumbo jets on the tarmac, ready to whisk passengers to various destinations for business, education, or family visits. "Oh thank goodness," a hefty man in a suit and sweat-drenched shirt exclaims, gripping my shoulder. I don't recognize him. "Oh hell, sorry buddy. I saw U of M on your bag and assumed you were another American." "I am," I reply, stretching out the words to convey some unease. "Apologies, but after two weeks surrounded solely by Asians, you start to lose it. No basketball scores, no small talk about the weather. Just 'ching chong ching chong chong' all day long." I despise people like him. However, my mood is too buoyant today to let such encounters dampen it. I merely nod and continue gazing out the window. "I'm Don, by the way." He extends a clammy hand toward me. It would be simple to decline, but then he'd likely direct his chatter at me. We shake hands. "Pete," I say, looking beyond Don to see the Chinese passengers keeping their distance. "Do you visit China often? I fly out here about twelve times a year. Used to be in real estate, selling houses. Now I sell brand names. Not actual products, just the names. Crazy, huh? So what do you do, Pat? Are you arriving or departing? Do you live in LA or just passing through? Where are you headed?" I turn my attention back to the plane. It's not worth correcting him on my name. Besides, the gate attendant is preparing for boarding. "Not where; when. I'm a time traveler." Don scoffs. "You're what?!" "I travel through time. And this," I gesture toward the plane, "is my ticket there." "You're messed up, man. Time travel? I'm not gullible." "We'll see in six hours."

A sci-fi tale where humans are the true monsters. They're devouring me completely. Bit by bit, these parasites consume every part of my body until my skin dries, cracks, and ultimately perishes. Their thirst knows no bounds, and their hunger is never satisfied. They ravage my flesh and drain my blood. It wasn't always this way. Once, my children—the life I nurtured from my own being—lived in harmony with me, taking only what was necessary for survival and allowing everything else to thrive. But over time, this changed. They multiplied relentlessly and were never satisfied staying in one place. In the past, they sustained themselves with what they found on my surface. As they grew and spread across my body, this was no longer enough. They stripped my skin for food and drained my blood for drink. Their machines spewed thick, oily smoke into my lungs, making it difficult for me to breathe. It won't be long now—I'm dying. My temperature has soared, and cracks are forming in my flesh. Blood spills from the wounds, destroying everything in its path. My skin is parched, and the air is nearly unbearable to breathe. These monsters I created have retreated to the few remaining safe havens, awaiting the inevitable. Selfishness, greed, lust, and hatred have destroyed both me and my children—and all I can do is weep helplessly. These *humans* have sealed their own fate.

If you had to choose, which of your prompt responses would you consider your best? The beach was stunning that day, with the Sun shining brightly, reflecting off the ocean, though my sunglasses made it bearable. As I gazed at the clear sky, my dog Henry began barking frantically. This wouldn't have concerned me if it weren't his alert bark. I quickly stood up from the sand and started scanning the surroundings. The only possible explanation in my mind was that a body had washed ashore. I glanced at Henry, who seemed to be signaling in every direction. I tried to soothe him with a pat, and he calmed a bit. He focused his barking towards the dunes behind me. Letting him track the scent, I gave him the command to proceed. He dashed off, with me sprinting to keep pace, heading to the top of a nearby dune. Once there, he stopped, looked at me, and barked once. Joining him, I scanned the area and saw Henry was staring at the ocean. Then I noticed it: the water was receding from the shore, rushing towards a massive wave further out. A tsunami. The beach was crowded with people. I frantically waved and shouted to warn them about the impending disaster, but no one noticed. I wanted to run and alert them, but my legs felt paralyzed. Henry sat beside me and quickly dozed off. The tsunami claimed over 200 lives on that beach, and all I could do was watch. As it turned out, Henry was an exceptional corpse-detection dog. Sometimes, he just found them a bit too early.

You're locked in a Scrabble match with the devil for your soul. "SON OF A BITCH," he shouted, considering flipping the board. "Satan, my kids are asleep, could you keep it down?" I replied calmly. His eyes burned with anger, contempt radiating from his look. "Did you take out ALL the vowels?" he asked through clenched teeth. I shook the letter bag at him. "Does it sound like anything's missing? I know you're upset, but show some decorum, Satan," I said, perhaps too sharply. He muttered under his breath and returned to struggling with his letters. Eventually, he managed to lay down "glare," and I chuckled softly. Words started flowing smoothly until I was left with just one letter. Satan grinned, holding a twenty-point lead and one letter left. I placed the "X" above the "I" for a triple letter score, leaning back with a smile. "XI! That's not a word!" he protested loudly. "The kids, Satan. The kids," I reminded him, tossing him the Scrabble dictionary. Moments later, he begrudgingly packed the letters back into the bag while I cleared the mugs. As he headed for the door, I asked, "See you next week?" "Yeah, same time as always?" he replied. "Of course, you'll beat me one day. You've really improved," I noted as he mumbled on his way out.

A group of muggers tailed someone into an alley. Unfortunately, it was the worst choice they could have made. I remembered her well. The three of us followed her, amused that a girl would wander this area, at this hour, alone, and then willingly enter an alley. When we demanded her money, she turned her nose up at us. "Why would I give you my money?" she asked, her lip curling as she assessed us. We assumed she was just a wealthy, spoiled person. Fools. I gave her a minor cut on her cheekbone—enough to scar and remind her of us, to instill fear and ensure she stayed within the safety of her home. I regret that deeply. A splash of water jolted me awake. "No falling asleep now!" a cheerful voice said. "You haven't learned your place yet." The blonde stood over me, her icy blue eyes piercing my soul, even as the brand seared my skin. "There. That should stop the bleeding." The smell of burnt flesh and blood overwhelmed me as I tried to scream, but my voice was lost. I watched her touch the stitches on her cheek through my one remaining eye.
